column7: General Information
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column7: Woodside is a global energy company founded in Australia. We provide reliable and affordable energy to help people lead better lives. Driven by a spirit of innovation and determination, we established Australia's liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry 35 years ago and supply a growing customer base.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Woodside's list of entities includes Woodside Energy Group, Woodside Burrup Pty, and Woodside Energy Global Holdings.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: The Annual Report 2023 summarizes WoodsideÃ¢ÂÂs operations and activities for the 12 months ended 31 December 2023 and its financial position as of 31 December 2023. Shareholders can communicate directly with Woodside by submitting questions or comments on the Contact Us section of our website.

In 2023, the Board adopted a Mandatory Clawback Policy consistent with the requirements of Section 303.A14 of the New York Stock Exchange Listed Company Manual. Where the Company is required to prepare an accounting restatement due to material non-compliance with any financial reporting requirements under the securities laws, the Company will recoup the erroneously awarded incentive-based compensation by such Mandatory Clawback Policy.
Pricewaterhouse Cooper (PWC) provides external assurance for the FY23 report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Woodside's strategy is to thrive through the energy transition by building a low-cost, lower-carbon, profitable, resilient, and diversified portfolio. Our pipeline of longer-term opportunities across different commodities supports this. Our significant growth projects, including Sangomar, Scarborough, and Trion, are well-placed to support our customers' demand needs.
Woodside's total employees as of 2023 was 4,610.
Woodside's non-fixed employees consist of part-time workers and the traineeship program, which totals 296 workers.
The Board committees of Woodside consist of the Audit & Risk Committee, Human Resource & Compensation Committee, Nomination & Governance Committee, and Sustainability Committee.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The Board manages its succession planning with the assistance of the Nominations & Governance Committee, which annually reviews the Board's size, composition, and diversity. The review considers the Board skills matrix and each director's tenure.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Richard Goyder will be the chairman for the reporting period.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The central roles of the Board are to set the strategic direction for the Company, to select and appoint the Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer (CEO), and to oversee the Company's management and business activities.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board delegates the reserve power to the CEO and senior management by appointing and removing the CEO, any other executive Directors and the Company Secretary and determining their remuneration and conditions of service, including any financial incentives.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Sustainability Committee is responsible for assisting the Board in meeting its oversight responsibilities regarding the Company's sustainability policies and practices, as outlined in the Committee Charter. The Committee receives regular briefings and education on climate change from Woodside's Senior Executive, who is responsible for informing its oversight of related matters with input from climate change science and expert advice.

The Board has approved a Directors' Conflict of Interest Policy, which applies if there is or maybe there is a conflict between a director's interests or the duties he or she owes to another company and the responsibilities he or she owes to Woodside. Directors must disclose circumstances that may affect, or be perceived to influence, their ability to exercise independent judgement so that the Board can assess independence regularly.

column13: EthicsPoint at Woodside provides employees a confidential platform to report ethical concerns or violations. Facilitating transparent communication and resolution of moral issues promotes accountability and integrity within the organisation.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board's skills and competencies include leadership and culture, financial acumen, business strategy, commercial, sustainability and stakeholder management, climate change, people and capability, and international industry.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Nominations & Governance Committee is responsible for evaluating Board candidates and recommending individuals for appointment to the Board. The Committee evaluates prospective candidates against various criteria, including the skills, experience, expertise, and diversity that will best complement the Board's current effectiveness. The Board may engage an independent recruitment firm to search for suitable candidates.

Executive remuneration is reviewed annually based on each individual's accountabilities, experience, and performance. FAR (fixed annual reward) and VAR (variable annual reward) are compared against domestic and international competitors at the target to maintain Woodside's capacity to attract and retain talent and ensure appropriate motivation is provided to Executives to deliver on the Company's strategic objectives.
Woodside Executive Incentive Scheme (EIS) consists of fixed and variable annual rewards (fixed and variable remuneration).
Total Executive Incentive Scheme (EIS) as of 2023 was USD 6.9 Million.

"We continued to review our approach to Scope 3 targets in response to investor feedback and have decided to supplement our existing investment target with a new complementary emissions abatement target. We have evolved our climate disclosures, which will be put to an advisory shareholder vote at our 2024 Annual General Meeting." -Richard Goyder.

Decommissioning commitments are integrated into project planning from the earliest stages of development to the end of field life. We work with global contractors to safely remove facilities and plug and abandon wells no longer required for our operations. We also work with regulators to deliver our decommissioning commitments.

column13: Woodside's Plug and Abandonment (P&A) campaign ensures responsible decommissioning of oil and gas wells, adhering to strict environmental and safety standards. By effectively sealing wells and restoring sites, Woodside upholds its commitment to environmental stewardship and regulatory compliance in the energy industry.
column20: Plug and abandonment (P&A) campaign, Xmas trees, riser turret mooring

column7: Woodside Health and Safety Policy outlines the objectives and principles that shape our approach, which is consistent across all our business operations. When assessing safety risks, we consider the potential negative impacts of our business activities on communities and our workforce, including impacts on human rights. We implement systems and processes to identify, assess, and control safety risks by applying the hierarchy of controls.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: The Our Voice Survey at Woodside gathers employee feedback to enhance workplace culture and organisational effectiveness. Through this initiative, Woodside fosters an environment of inclusivity and continuous improvement, valuing the input and perspectives of its workforce.
column20: Our Voice Survey, inclusive culture, inclusive leadership

column13: At Woodside, the Ethics and Compliance Team is dedicated to upholding the highest standards of integrity and legal adherence across all operations. Through proactive oversight and robust training initiatives, they ensure that ethical principles are integrated into every aspect of the company's activities.
column20: Ethics and Compliance Team, governance structures, laws and regulation

column7: Woodside is a member of the American Petroleum Institute, AMEXHI, H2KOREA, International Gas Union, Business Council of Australia, and the Australian Pipelines and Gas Association.
